course.title: Problem Solving (C++)
course.description: Learn C++ fundamentals from scratch. loops, functions, arrays, pointers, file I/O, and basic OOP â€” and build a solid programming foundation.

sections.title: 3D Array Coding Question
Where to go next?
sections.content:
ðŸ“Œ Next Steps: Where to Go & What to Do

Congratulations! Youâ€™ve completed the C++ Fundamentals course. Now itâ€™s time to apply your skills, reinforce your learning, and move forward.

1. Practice Regularly

Complete all coding exercises and MCQs to solidify your understanding.

Try modifying existing programs and creating small projects, e.g., a calculator, student database, or simple game.

2. Explore Advanced C++ Topics

Object-Oriented Programming in depth (inheritance, polymorphism, templates)

Data structures like arrays, linked lists, stacks, queues, and trees

File handling in detail, including binary files

Memory management and smart pointers

3. Build Projects

Apply what you learned by building small programs or mini-projects.

Examples:

Bank management system

Student grading system

Inventory tracker

Simple text-based game

4. Prepare for Assessments

Use the 120+ MCQs to test your knowledge.

Revisit topics where you feel less confident.

5. Continue Your Learning Journey

Take intermediate or advanced C++ courses to deepen your understanding.

Learn about data structures & algorithms to prepare for programming challenges and interviews.

Explore game development, competitive programming, or system-level programming.

6. Stay Engaged

Join coding communities or forums to discuss problems and solutions.

Try pair programming or mentoring beginners to reinforce your knowledge.

questions.questionText: Which keyword is used to define a class in C++?

Which access specifier allows members to be accessed outside the class?

options: Hiding data and providing methods to access it

questions.questionText: Which of the following creates an object of class Car?

options: To prevent access from member functions

sections.title: OOP 2 Coding Questions (hard)
OOP 2 Coding Questions (easy)
File Functions

questions.questionText: Which header file must be included to perform file input and output in C++?
What happens if you open a file with ofstream without specifying any flags and the file already exists?
What is the purpose of the eof() function when reading from a file using ifstream?
options: To check if the file is open
To check if an error occurred
To check if the end of the file has been reached
To rewind the file to the beginning

questions.questionText: If a text file contains extra spaces between words, which method will automatically skip the extra spaces when reading individual words?
Which class is used for writing data to files in C++?
What happens if a text file contains double values (like 12.7 45.3) and you try to read them into int variables using ifstream?
options: The program crashes with an error.
The double values are automatically rounded before storing into int variables.
The decimal parts are discarded (truncated) and only the integer parts are stored.
The double values are skipped completely during reading.

questions.questionText: What is the correct use of put() in file output?
options: To read a word from the file
To write a single character to a file
To write a string to a file
To close the file after writing

questions.questionText: Which function is used to read a single character from a file?
Which function is used to check if a file has failed to open in C++?
Which mode is used to open a file in append mode, meaning new data is added at the end of the file?

options: Creates a file named data.txt with content 'Hello'

questions.questionText: What does the seekp() function do in ofstream?
options: Sets the position for the next write operation
Reads a character from the specified position
Checks if the file is open

questions.questionText: How do you check if a file was successfully opened?
What is the default mode for ofstream?

options: Prints the first line of data.txt

questions.questionText: Which operator is used to write data to a file using ofstream?
What is the purpose of the flush() function in file output?
options: To clear the buffer and write all pending data to the file
To read data from the file

questions.questionText: Which of the following is true about file streams in C++?
options: You can only open one file at a time.
File streams are part of the iostream library.
File streams cannot be used with strings.

questions.questionText: Which of the following is the correct syntax for defining an enum class in C++?
options: enum class Color { Red, Green, Blue };
class enum Color { Red, Green, Blue };

questions.questionText: What is the default underlying type of an enum in C++?
In C++, what is the benefit of using the scope resolution operator :: with enums?
options: It allows assigning default values to enums.
It prevents enum values from being accessed outside the enum.
It avoids name conflicts by accessing enum members with full qualification.

questions.questionText: Which of the following is a correct way to declare an enum in C++?

What will be the value of Low in the following enum?
 enum Level { Low = 1, Medium, High = 10 };
How do you define an enum class with a specific underlying type?
options: enum class Color : char { Red, Green, Blue };
enum class Color { Red: char, Green: char, Blue: char };
enum class Color (Red, Green, Blue): char;
enum class Color using char { Red, Green, Blue };

questions.questionText: Which of the following is the correct way to declare a structure in C++?
options: struct Person { int age; float height; };
structure Person { int age; float height; };
structure Person { int: age, height: float; };

questions.questionText: Which of the following is the correct way to access a structure member in C++?
Which statement correctly describes a struct in C++?
options: Structs are always public by default.
Structs are identical to classes except for default access control.

questions.questionText: What is the difference between struct and class in C++?
options: Structs use private access by default, classes use public.
Classes use private access by default, structs use public.

questions.questionText: Which of the following is true about struct initialization in C++?
options: You must always use a constructor.
You can initialize members using curly braces {}.
You cannot initialize members at declaration.
Only global structs can be initialized.

sections.title: Reverse string & number
Pointers & Recursion Coding Question
Dynamic Memory Allocation
sections.content:
Dynamic Memory Allocation Using Pointers in C++

In C++, dynamic memory allocation allows you to request memory at runtime, instead of defining the size of arrays or variables at compile time. This is useful when the amount of memory needed is not known in advance.

Key Points:

Using new to allocate memory

You can create a variable or an array on the heap using the new operator.

Example for a single variable:

int* ptr = new int;  // allocates memory for one int
*ptr = 10;           // assign value using the pointer


Example for an array:

int size = 5;
int* arr = new int[size];  // allocates memory for an array of 5 integers


Accessing the allocated memory

Use the pointer with * (dereference) for a single variable.

Use the pointer with array indexing for arrays:

arr[0] = 10;
arr[1] = 20;


Releasing memory with delete

Memory allocated dynamically is not automatically freed. You must release it using delete to avoid memory leaks.

For a single variable:

delete ptr;


For an array:

delete[] arr;


Benefits of dynamic memory

Allows flexibility in programs when the size of data is not known beforehand.

Helps manage memory efficiently by allocating and freeing as needed.

Caution:

Always pair new with delete (or new[] with delete[]).

Avoid using memory after it has been deleted (dangling pointers).

questions.questionText: What is the correct way to declare a pointer to an integer in C++?
What does the & operator do when used with a variable?
options: Returns the address of the variable

questions.questionText: What does the * operator do when used with a pointer variable?
options: Dereferences the pointer to access the value

questions.questionText: Which of the following is true about pointers in C++?
options: Pointers are not allowed in functions

questions.questionText: What happens if you dereference a null pointer?
Check Point... What is the output? #include <iostream> using namespace std; int main() { int a = 5, b = 10; int* p = &a; *p = b; cout << a; return 0; }
Check Point... Which statement correctly frees dynamically allocated memory?
options: Both B and C depending on allocation

sections.title: introduction to course
sections.content:
ðŸ”° Course Introduction: C++ Fundamentals

Before starting the course: Please press the â€œRequest Accessâ€ button and follow the steps to enroll. Once access is granted, you can start learning immediately.

This course is designed to give you a strong and practical foundation in C++ programming.
Whether you are completely new to programming or want to strengthen your core skills, this course will guide you step by step from the basics to essential real-world concepts through a combination of engaging video lessons and clear written explanations.

ðŸ“˜ What Youâ€™ll Learn

In this course, we will cover the core fundamentals of C++, including:

Variables, data types, and operators

Control flow using if statements, for loops, and while loops

Functions and how to break programs into reusable parts

Arrays (1D, 2D, and 3D) and working with data efficiently

Recursion and how functions can call themselves

Pointers and memory basics in C++

Text file input/output (File I/O) for reading and writing files

Basic Object-Oriented Programming (OOP) concepts

Structures (struct) and enumerations (enum)

Each topic is taught using video tutorials supported by concise text explanations and examples, making it easy to follow, practice, and review at your own pace.

ðŸŽ¯ Course Features & Purpose

By the end of this course, you will:

Build a solid C++ foundation

Understand core programming concepts used in many languages

Be ready to move on to advanced C++, data structures, or game development

Gain the confidence to write, understand, and debug your own programs

Test your skills with 120+ multiple-choice questions (MCQs) and 10+ hands-on coding exercises

This course focuses on learning by understanding and uses a video + text learning approach, making it ideal for beginners who want a strong, flexible, and interactive start in C++.

options: a) Line 10 base case, line 6 recursive call
b) Line 6 base case, line 10 recursive call
c) Line 8 recursive call, line 10 base case
d) Line 6 recursive call, line 8 base case

sections.title: 1D Array Coding Question
Bubble sort and Selection sort
sections.content:
What Is Sorting?

Sorting is the process of arranging data in a specific order, usually ascending (smallest to largest) or descending (largest to smallest).

Why sorting is important:

Makes data easier to read

Improves searching speed

Used in databases, leaderboards, rankings, and algorithms

Example

Unsorted:

[5, 3, 1, 4]


Sorted (ascending):

[1, 3, 4, 5]

Bubble Sort (Step by Step)
Idea

Bubble Sort compares adjacent elements and swaps them if they are in the wrong order.
Large values gradually move to the end of the array.

Example

Array:

[5, 3, 1, 4]

Pass 1

Compare 5 and 3 â†’ swap:

[3, 5, 1, 4]


Compare 5 and 1 â†’ swap:

[3, 1, 5, 4]


Compare 5 and 4 â†’ swap:

[3, 1, 4, 5]


ðŸ‘‰ Largest value 5 is now in its correct position.

Pass 2

Compare 3 and 1 â†’ swap:

[1, 3, 4, 5]


Compare 3 and 4 â†’ no swap.

Pass 3

Compare 1 and 3 â†’ no swap.
Array is fully sorted.

Final Result
[1, 3, 4, 5]

Bubble Sort C++ Code
void bubbleSort(int arr[], int n) {
    for(int i = 0; i < n - 1; i++) {
        for(int j = 0; j < n - i - 1; j++) {
            if(arr[j] > arr[j + 1]) {
                swap(arr[j], arr[j + 1]);
            }
        }
    }
}

Selection Sort (Step by Step)
Idea

Selection Sort finds the smallest element and puts it in its correct position.

Example

Array:

[5, 3, 1, 4]

Pass 1 (Index 0)

Smallest value is 1 â†’ swap with first element:

[1, 3, 5, 4]

Pass 2 (Index 1)

Remaining array: [3, 5, 4]
Smallest value is 3 â†’ already correct:

[1, 3, 5, 4]

Pass 3 (Index 2)

Remaining array: [5, 4]
Smallest value is 4 â†’ swap:

[1, 3, 4, 5]

Final Result
[1, 3, 4, 5]

Selection Sort C++ Code
void selectionSort(int arr[], int n) {
    for(int i = 0; i < n - 1; i++) {
        int minIndex = i;

        for(int j = i + 1; j < n; j++) {
            if(arr[j] < arr[minIndex]) {
                minIndex = j;
            }
        }

        swap(arr[i], arr[minIndex]);
    }
}

Key Difference
Bubble Sort	                 Selection Sort
Swaps many times	         Swaps once per pass
Moves large values right	 Moves small values left
Easy to visualize	         Easy to reason

Memory Trick

Bubble Sort: Compare neighbors and swap

Selection Sort: Select the smallest and place it

sections.title: Binary Search Vs Linear Search
sections.content:
Linear Search vs Binary Search

Searching is the process of finding a specific value in a collection of data such as an array. Two common searching algorithms are Linear Search and Binary Search.

Linear Search:

Linear Search checks each element one by one until the target value is found or the array ends.

Works on sorted and unsorted data

Easy to understand and implement

Slow for large datasets

Time Complexity: O(n)

C++ Code Example
int linearSearch(int arr[], int n, int target) {
    for(int i = 0; i < n; i++) {
        if(arr[i] == target)
            return i;
    }
    return -1;
}

Step-by-Step Debugging Example

Array: [4, 7, 1, 9, 3]
Target: 9

Check 4 â†’ not a match

Check 7 â†’ not a match

Check 1 â†’ not a match

Check 9 â†’ âœ… found

Result: Found at index 3

Binary Search:

Binary Search is a faster algorithm that repeatedly divides the search range in half.

âš ï¸ The array must be sorted before using binary search.

Very fast for large datasets

Slightly more complex than linear search

Time Complexity: O(log n)

C++ Code Example
int binarySearch(int arr[], int n, int target) {
    int left = 0;
    int right = n - 1;

    while(left <= right) {
        int mid = (left + right) / 2;

        if(arr[mid] == target)
            return mid;
        else if(arr[mid] < target)
            left = mid + 1;
        else
            right = mid - 1;
    }
    return -1;
}

Important Note (Very Common Mistake)

In binary search, the variables left, right, and mid represent indexes, not the actual values inside the array.

Example
int arr[] = {2, 4, 6, 8, 10};
int n = 5;

left = 0;
right = n - 1; // right = 4, NOT 10


left â†’ first index

right â†’ last index

mid â†’ index between them

Binary search always compares:

arr[mid]


not mid itself.

âœ… Rule to remember: Binary search works with indexes, not values.

Step-by-Step Debugging Example (Binary Search)

Sorted Array: [2, 4, 6, 8, 10]
Target: 8

Step 1

left = 0, right = 4

mid = (0 + 4) / 2 = 2

arr[2] = 6 â†’ target is larger
â†’ Move right

Step 2

left = 3, right = 4

mid = (3 + 4) / 2 = 3

arr[3] = 8 â†’ âœ… found

Result: Found at index 3

Quick Comparison
Linear Search	Binary Search
Any order	    Sorted only
O(n)	        O(log n)
Simple	        Faster

sections.title: Revision C++
sections.content:
This video provides a clear and structured introduction to C++ fundamentals. Topics include basic syntax, variables, data types, input/output, operators, control flow (if-else and loops), and functions. Designed for students and beginners, this tutorial helps build a strong foundation in C++ programming and problem-solving skills.

Link to download : https://youtu.be/DMWD7wfhgNY?si=jyMzcHhHVrpiTV3b
